The water park is ridiculously over priced for 3 slides and a lazy river. Guests should be allowed to use it without being charged at all. The water park is also a long walk, elevator, and funicular ride away from Las Casitas. We found two huge water bugs in our casita on 2 separate occasions (1 dead, 1 nearly dead). There are no screens on the windows or doors to the balconies so you cannot leave them open. The shades on the windows are falling apart. We found broken glass on the floor in the bedroom that our children were in which must have been there from a previous guest. Housekeeping did not have vacuum cleaners - only brooms and damp mops so they did not do a great job of cleaning. Food at outside eateries was also less than excellent. We tried Metropol and Estacion. The burger at Metropol was dry and tasteless. The mosquitos and cats dodging around Estacion made it difficult to enjoy our meals. All in all we spent a great deal of money at a hotel that did not meet our expectations.

Reviews.Title: “Great resort, worth the trip out east!”
Reviews.Author: BruceAMD
Reviews.Content: We had a wonderful stay here. Staff was great, room on the ocean beautiful, adjacent to the El Conquistador so plenty to do. I would recommend the breakfast buffet but the resort restaurants were very pricey and food very average. I would recomment going to some local places such as the La Estacion and Pasion, both authentic, great food and reasonably prices. Be sure you're prepared to pay the resort fee, an added charge at checkout.

Reviews.Title: “The best place to stay in Puerto Rico!”
Reviews.Author: travel0818
Reviews.Content: The Las Casitas Village Waldorf Astoria is the sister resort to El Conquistador. It's basically the same resort but nicer/better accommodations (the rooms are nicer, check it out on Trip Advisor). This Waldorf Astoria resort is definitely the best place to stay in Puerto Rico. It's in Fajardo, which is where you want to stay most of your trip (San Juan resorts don't offer much beauty, they're in the city (which has slum areas), and the beaches aren't that nice). Las Casitas in Fajardo offers nice room accomodations and access to spa, water park, nice private beach/ferry to private island (Palomino) and water activities, as well as beautiful scenery. Places you gotta go while in PR: -Old San Juan -La Bombonera restaurant in Old San Juan (try the mallorcas!) -16th century forts -Las Casitas Village Waldorf Astoria -Bio-bay kayaking excursion (if there is no moon or half moon) -Aquafari excursion -Ferry to Culebra (go to Flamenco beach, hike to Carlos Rosario and other beach to the right ) -Rent a car to travel from San Juan to Fajardo and to the Culebra ferry and other excursions. Also, definitely bring your own snorkling gear, a pad lock or some sort of lock for the lockers at Culebra and a benedryl pen for the bug bites. Enjoy your vacation!

Reviews.Title: “Paradise in Puerto Rico!”
Reviews.Author: delbymom
Reviews.Content: We just returned from our 4th year at Las Casitas and once again, it was a truly perfect vacation. We hated to leave! Beautiful surroundings, great accomodations in our 2 bedroom ocean view casita, excellent service, especially from our butler, Carlos, and all the girls at the Manor House. This resort has everything for a couple/family to enjoy and we have already booked our trip for next year and can't wait to return to Paradise!!

Reviews.Title: “Hidden paradise”
Reviews.Author: firecanyon
Reviews.Content: Just got back from this wonderful vacation! Can't wait to return. Beautiful place, beautiful weather. Wonderful experience. Almost lost my daughter's new ipod touch and it was returned to us by Albert.. Sooo grateful!!!

Reviews.Title: “Grand old Place ,with bad food”
Reviews.Author: Garryauspa19
Reviews.Content: We wanted to See the El Yunque rain forest nearby and decided to stay for 2 nights in this place. The setting is nice and the place is just large and a little outdated . These Grand Hotels were fashionable in the late 30th and it cavernous premisses did impress some people. However now more private places are preferred with good restaurants and service. To say at least ,this place ,in the older part is very outdated and needs a complete workover. The rooms even with their terrific view show their age. They are clean but not spotless. The restaurants,we tried a sandwich(just good for the waste basket) and a Chinese place do not meet the proclaimed standard of this place. So for dinner ,rent a car and eat off the premisses. When we send an email to the food manager ,he was disappointed that we will not visit this place again. So if you want to have a real luxury hotel ,take the ferry to Vieques and stay at the really renovated W Hotel. It is expensive but worth the money.

Reviews.Title: “Would be 5* if not for housekeeping”
Reviews.Author: DAVEBUCK
Reviews.Content: First of all, Las Casitas are beautiful and the perfect place for any family with children of any age! The rooms are beautiful and the activities are plentiful for all. Kids Camp, Teen lounge, Water Park, excellent restaurants, Casino, Spa, and private Island. There is a beautiful golf course, Tennis, horseback riding, and it is real near El Yunke forest. There are excellent restaurants right near the hotel as well. The pools are magnificent! My only complaint has to do with housekeeping. Sometimes we didn't get towels and another time housekeeping didn't show up until my 3rd call at 7 pm. Fortunately, the managers did respond and within 30 minutes all problems were resolved. So I would give it 4.5 *. It is too bad housekeeping took away the last star. However, our family of 4 will be returning next year. If you don't mind spending a little time correcting the issues and reviewing the bill, it is a great place! I think tipping the manger will solve the housekeeping issue. I found out people paid lots of different amounts for their rooms so search around before booking. One other point, the hotel has a lot of hidden charges or rather not apparent charges so if your room charge is $400, expect another 20% of "resort fees" and taxes!!

Reviews.Title: “Romance, Luxury & Paradise”
Reviews.Author: WriterEsq
Reviews.Content: My husband and I chose Las Casitas Village on the recommendation of a friend who had recently stayed here. I have been coming to Puerto Rico for vacations with my family since 1986, and have usually stayed in the Isla Verde / San Juan area. We decided to try some place new for 4 nights before going to meet the rest of my family in San Juan. Boy was I glad that we did. After much debate, we decided to rent a car and am so glad that we did. The restaurants located right outside of the hotel were incredible (La Estacion / Pasion) and well worth the car rental alone. The hotel is located 33 miles from the airport, and the shuttle to and from the hotel was pricey (I believe it was $74 per person round trip). When we arrived at the airport, it was pouring and the 33 miles took us about 90 minutes to do. But once arrived, holy cow! The hotel was beautiful. Sprawling grounds as we drove up, free parking for Las Casitas guests and we were greeted with bottled water. No problems at all with check in and we were given a brief tour of the immediate area. Las Casitas was gorgeous. It's own little area with 2 pools, restaurant, and very close to the amazing Golden Door Spa, which we tried and loved (though pricey!) Golf carts will take you everywhere, but we walked wherever we wanted to go. Our room was the best part. We were upgraded to a 1 BR, with a kitchenette, hot tub on the back porch and the most gorgeous ocean view I have ever seen - with 2 lounge chairs. We never needed to leave the room. I have to say, the great part about our stay is that it wasn't very crowded. There is a vehicular (not sure if that's what it's called), takes you down to the ferry where you go to the beach. We never had to wait, but I'm sure that if it was crowded, it could get annoying. Also, because it wasn't crowded at the resort, the ferries to Palomino Island (where the beach) is, only ran every hour, even on the weekends. Still, Palomino was beautiful and it has everything you'd need for a day at the beach (restaurants, bathrooms, horse back riding). During one of the days, the weather wasn't so great, and we ended up going to the Coqui Water Park. It would be great for kids, but we found it fun for a couple of hours as adults! Casino is small, but lots of cute little stores to wander into. Starbucks was key! Some great things we did: Kayak Adventures - great company and we did the rainforest / bio bay combo. Golden Door Spa: My husband did a Signature massage and I did the Spirit of LIfe combo - which was awesome!! Something unique other than then the regular massage I always do. Food: La Estacion had the best skirt steak mofongo I've ever had in my life. I'm still dreaming about it. It's my new favorite restaurant in the world (no joke!) Grocery Store: the one close by the resort has everything you need. Even had Luna Bars and Kashi cereal for lower prices than I pay in Manhattan. If only I could do my grocery shopping in Puerto Rico! The lunch place by the main pool was awesome. We had these great foccacia pizza things that were amazing. I wish we had done the Culebra Island / Flamingo Beach trip that everyone was raving about. We ran out of time. Overall - great service, great place - and try to eat / book trips outside of the resort.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful Lodgings, Overpriced Amenities”
Reviews.Author: Stealthray
Reviews.Content: Las Casitas is a selection of town home style villas adjacent to the El Conquistador resort. We enjoyed a two bedroom villa and were satisfied with the quality of the rooms. Las Casitas guests can use all of the resort facilities of El Conquistador as well as several other pools exclusive for Las Casitas guests. Palamino Island is a nice venture, but be forewarned, no coolers! This posed a problem on several occasions as they reduced the 30 minute ferry to only once an hour as well as shut down shops on the island early due to few customers. All facilities greatly overcharge for food and beverage. Pina coladas run $15 and a hot dog $9. I love to spend while on vacation but hate gouge prices. For those in Las Casitas you can grocery shop in Fajardo as well as dine at a few medium quality establishments out in town. Rental car is cheap and highly recommended!

Reviews.Title: “My stay at the Las Casitas resort”
Reviews.Author: captainmax40
Reviews.Content: My stay at the Las Casitas was a very nice stay this is our second time and i we first got there they did not give us joining rooms. When we asked for joining rooms. Though we got a better room that said home to us. The hotel is a very nice hotel and if you have kids you should take them on the golf cart to the main hotel it is very fun. The restaurants there were fantastic the breakfast places have a breakfast buffet or you can have a sit down breakfast.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful but Needs Improvement”
Reviews.Author: AzNative72
Reviews.Content: I would like to qualify my response but stating that I have stayed in many high end resorts throughout the world and usually never complain about having the privilege of staying in such style, but I guess there is always an exception. We rented a three bedroom casita in the newer section of the resort. The room was beautiful and the view was spectacular. The staff was friendly but definitely not very organized. We waited many times for the shuttle to and from the main hotel to only have to fight with other guests for space. I would have expected for this level of hotel that the guests would not have had to compete for basic services. The food on site was not great and the drinks were half the size at the same cost of other resorts of the same level. The pools were dated and not heated. There were quite a few hidden fees such as a $125/day fee for resort use (really?), and it is an additional $15 (kids)/ $18(adults) to use the water park with 3 slides. I would recommend this resort to people between the ages of 25-60 due to the lack of activities for children and poor service to transport older guests (my mother is handicapped and got to see very little of the resort due to the service and terrain). Puerto Rico was beautiful, but many times wished we were staying at The Reef at the Atlantis. It would have been the same cost with so many more perks and better service.

Reviews.Title: “Lovely, if you are into resorts”
Reviews.Author: nancyvt_77
Reviews.Content: I travelled to Las Casitas with my husband and 3 yr old son for a late winter getaway. It is a great setting with lots of stuff to see and do. I think we were there at a fairly uncrowded time, we never had problems waiting on line or getting reservations, etc. My son was in love with the catamaran shuttles to the beach and the faniculars. Be forewarned, it is a resort with resort prices for EVERYTHING.

Reviews.Title: “Truly Paradise”
Reviews.Author: writeway00
Reviews.Content: I took my children and parents to the resort for Spring Break. I wanted a beautiful, peaceful setting where my parents and I could relax, but still interesting enough to keep the kids occupied. This was it!! The grounds were beautiful, the views from my one bedroom suite were breathtaking! My parents had a standard room and that was nice too. The front desk service and concierge were very helpful and the kids LOVED the waterpark and pools. The food at the hotel was pricey and I'd rate it as just okay. We had a car, though, and went into town most evenings for dinner. Much better quality and value! We'd definitely go back!

Reviews.Title: “I wish we rented a car!”
Reviews.Author: Abigail96
Reviews.Content: We just returned from Las Casitas Resort. We booked a 1BR suite for 4 nights and did not get the one that was pictured on their website. We got a first floor garden view in what we were told was the "old" part of the resort. After checking out, I asked my 17 year old (who speaks spanish and I do not) to ask one of the housekeepers if we could see a one bedroom. She was very accommodating and showed us what was pictured on the website. It was beautiful, considerably larger. We found the unit we stayed in to be very tight. My husband is 6'9" and our teens are both 6'1". We booked the Coqui Water Park package, which included a wonderful breakfast buffet, access to the water park and transfers for the four of us to and from the airport. I was told that if we book 3 nights, we get a fourth free. Our bill does not reflect a 4th free night, so I intend to call the resort. One thing that I was not told is that at the time of check in they let you know that they need to take $200 per day for incidentals on top of the regular bill. Make sure you call your credit card company to let them know that this transaction is coming up. Our card had a security alert on it and it added 20 minutes to our check in. (not the resorts fault). I wish we rented a car!!! Becasue we had a very large breakfast everyday, we chose to have another meal around 3 or 4 everyday. It seemed as though we lived in our bathing suits and for this reason, we chose casual resort restaurants. We got a bit sick of $15 cheeseburgers and $16 salads. One day we took the ferry to Palamino Island. It is absolutely beautiful. My husband ordered two drinks. The waitress on the beach brought them to us (not used to that kind of service...but very nice) "$24" she said. I have worked as a waitress all through college and I have worked for an airline for 14 years. Currently, I am in the Marketing field.....$24!!! Are you kidding. Two drinks in 8 oz plastic cups $24? If we had a car we could have gone to a grocery store and stocked up on snacks and bottled water etc, and we could have made use of the narrow galley kitchen in our unit. We asked about a shuttle from the hotel to the grocery store, and we were told that they did not offer that, but they could call a cab for us. The cab is $50 for a 5 mile round trip. By having a car we could have explored some of the authentic restaurants in Puerto Rico, and saved the $75 round trip per person for transfers to and from the airport which is an hour ride. We met some folks who travel here every year and they told us that is it $129 for a car for a week. Believe it or not we may come back, but we will be very specific about the room. Also, we would definitely rent a car so that we would not feel trapped on the resort.

Reviews.Title: “Overall great stay with a few things you should know”
Reviews.Author: jen30039
Reviews.Content: Vacation with a 15 year old and 12 year old for 5 nights. We were looking for easy access (direct flight and not too long drive), beach/swimmings with some other variety of interest points, so PR seemed perfect, with rainforest, Old San Juan, easy access, US dollar, English, etc...Overall, very nice resort. Agree with past reviewers that it is not 4+star, so as long as you don't expect that, it's ok. Grounds are gorgeous (Las Casitas and El Conquistador), big and ocean view always right there. Fun walking around after dinners, always something going on. Las Casitas: off to rocky start...when we arrived, there was water all throughout hallway to bedroom (1 bedroom villa, all ceramic tile so easy to dry), there was no rollaway bed that we were promised, and there were no blankets or sheets for sleeper sofa (which the kids ended up sharing all week b/c on day 3 when a rollaway finally became available, we were told (for the first time) that it was $45/DAY. On second day we finally got blankets for pull out, and kids could sleep together, so it was ok, though they preferred a rollaway for one since 1 boy/1 girl are getting a little old to sleep together, but they were fine even though it wasn't comfortable (bar poking the back). First dinner was at Buones Vista (sp) at El Con by big pool - food was mediocre and expensive: $70 for 2 beers, 2 cokes, 2 individual plain pizzas, 1 salad and 1 quesadilla. Shrimp on salad was not freshest. Back to Las Casitas: ocean view from balcony is gorgeous, service was good after bed and water (water issue took 3 calls/3 visits to resolve). I think water park (pool, lazy river and 3 slides) should be free if you stay. When we did water park, we arrived at 2:00, no chairs (not 1), very crowded, no tubes for floating or slides. Shame to pay for that. We did not, since we had water leaking into our villa for 3 days, and on 3rd day I asked for compensation, 4 tickets to water park. Concierge pleasantly agreed, and I'm thankful for that. I've never complained like that before, but was really feeling we were paying a lot for not such great service/ameneties, so at least that gesture made me feel like they were listening. We also had a close call going to Palimano Island. We arrived at boat at 9:45, and almost didn't get on (they go every hour) and have a 150 person capacity.. Also shame to miss that and feel the hotel should be able to accomodate large numbers of guests. If they take your money and promise you a private island, then they should have the means to get you there, even if they have to have an extra ferry for the 1 or 2 most popular hours. We made it, but dozens of others didn't, and had to wait around in hot sun till 11, b/c they couldn't really go exploring or else they'd risk losing a spot on the next ferry. No good. Again, we made it, so we felt lucky. At the island, there is some decent (not great) snorkeling, was great for kids. You have to pay for evverything (a raft, snorkel (we had some so brought from home), but lots of chairs, umbrellas, beach space, etc. Very nice. Best dining by a landslide: Las Estation, right outside of resort (take a right)...EXCELLENT, fresh, cheap compared to El Con. My kids have food allergies, adn they were willing to do whatever they could (plain grilled chix breast, etc...). We went there 2x. Their monfongo was better than Passion, and the second night I just wanted grilled shrimp, so they gave me the appetizer (pinchos)-2 skewers w/side of rice/beans. The huge platter arrived with many other additions, such as tostados (I htink), avocado, fresh lime, veggies, etc...Partner had pork loin (w/rice/beans) first night and ribs (upon recommendation of table next to us) second. Also superb (and he's very picky). I had the best mojito I've ever had at this place, but second night they had no mint, so I just had a beer. Rainforst a must, though don't expect too much from the animal kingdom other than a stray snail or tiny iguana. Oh, hte huge (2 foot iguanas) on Palimano Island are amazing. OK, overall great trip, El con getting old, but has a lot to do and good location.

Reviews.Title: “amazing accomodations and service with lots to do.”
Reviews.Author: highstandardschic
Reviews.Content: Our 2 BR 2 BA condo was huge, beautiful and spotless. The large balcony looked out onto the water. We had a pool 50 yards form our door and multiple other pools on the property. The service was amazing and Carlos, our concierge, was extremely friendly and helpful. He arranged our trip to the bioluminescent bay and dinner reservations and we got great tips about visiting the rainforest (definitely worth the trip). Always charming, never pushy. The restaurants are very expensive, but the food was good and the service impecable wherever we went. The water park was a bit crowded and there are not nearly enough inner tubes to use so we never got to go down the inner tube slide, but we still had fun (this is my only suggestion for improvement). Palomino island is lovely and our kids loved the horseback riding. We would return

Reviews.Title: “Amazing stay!”
Reviews.Author: Delaware012
Reviews.Content: We had a fabulous time at Las Casitas. We strongly recommend staying here vs. next door at main resort. It is worth the extra money. We had a little difficulty upon arriving as our villa only had one bed and did not have a pull out sofa as advertised. We had requested 2 beds but apparently most of the one bedroom villas only come with a king bed. Our butler, Ricardo, was fabulous. He stayed late and followed up to make sure we ended up with the correct room. He called us every day to make sure we had all the information we needed and even brought us a cake for our son's birthday. The room and view was beautiful. The infinity pool was great and hardly ever crowded. Several times we had the pool to ourselves! The gardens were peaceful and relaxing. We would definitely return and would absolutely request Ricardo as our butler! We had a terrific day at the Rain Forests and absolutely loved Culebra Island. We recommend flying to the island from the local airport as the tickets to the ferry sell out quickly. The bio bay tour was a terrific sight although the kayak ride there and back was difficult as there were too many boats. We dined outside the resort. There is a terrific restaurant right around the corner called El Station. Also the kioskos are great too! All in all, a terrific vacation!

Reviews.Title: “Fantastic Views - But eat elsewhere”
Reviews.Author: Tanklaw
Reviews.Content: To begin with, the scenery is incredible. If you enjoy the wonders of nature, this resort experience is not to be missed. Spectacular cliff-side views overlooking the ocean and marina must be seen to be believed. The service was also wonderful with all staff, from maid to concierge, being very friendly and willing to assist in any way possible. That being said, either be prepared to be gouged for food and room wi-fi services (although wi-fi is free in the internet cafe). While the food within the resort is very good, it is also very overpriced. If you have children, the cost of food can quickly become prohibitive. I highly recommend renting a car and driving to any of the many local restaurants. You will more than recoup the cost of the rental and will have the freedom to visit many of the other outstanding sights. Two of those restaurants would be La Estacion and Passions. Both are within five minutes drive of the front gate and both offer outstanding food. Neither restaurant looks like the "standard" restaurant, and are obviously "authentic" eateries. If you are looking a fantastic meal, try either restaurant. But do not expect fine dining with linen tablecloths. Do expect a relaxed atmosphere and friendly conversations with the owners and other patrons.

Reviews.Title: “Would visit over and over again - it's paradise!”
Reviews.Author: grammygirl40
Reviews.Content: We were a party of 12 (all family). Activities for all ages and abundant staff couldn't have been more helpful. Kudos to staff! Loved Palomino Island. I suggest placing a Carp on the dock in Palomino...we waited 1/2 hour on line under hot, hot sun in order to get onto the next boat back to the mainland. That was our only obstacle.

Reviews.Title: “BEAUTIFUL PROPERTY- GOING AGAIN 8/10/2010 - SERVICE NEEDS IMPROVEMENT”
Reviews.Author: daveshovelpan
Reviews.Content: This will be our 2nd time at this resort and we did enjoy it as long as you know a few things ahead of time.... We have been all over the carribean at high end hotels so we are used to 4-5 star hotels & service and have many other properties to compare this hotel to... We like PR because it is a quick flight for us from PA and no customs, etc to deal with... The property is gorgeous and huge. Pools are nice and my kids like the waterpark even though i think it should be included for hotel guests even though i know it would only just raise the daily rate. As many others stated, internet is horrible, golf cart service you can stand there for 45 minutes some nights and nobody cares... be prepared to do alot of walking. After dinner we didn't mind walking home to work off the food otherwise the carts will really frustrate you.. If you are a beach bum this place isn't for you.. You have to take a boat to a island and then your trapped there until the next ship comes back.. We had both ships break down one day and waited for 2 hours for chartered ships to help. It was a mess had the Grand Parents been with us it would of been a nightmare... We did enjoy the property, the room, the restaurants, & the waterpark so it was a good vacation but a 3 star at best... If you have kids Atlantis is very expensive but incredible.

Reviews.Title: “Another world................”
Reviews.Author: Nikdechef
Reviews.Content: Fun for all in beautiful surroundings, not cheap but you get what you pay for.

Reviews.Title: “Great stop-over”
Reviews.Author: lromo
Reviews.Content: We recently stayed at Las Casitas en route from St John to Houston and found the service to be exemplary. The guest services personnel were great and we received the personalized assistance that is hard to come by in the Caribbean. If you make it to Las Casitas look up Carlos Mangual he will go above and beyond in making sure that your stay is flawless

Reviews.Title: “Hotel was very nice, just be prepared to spend $$”
Reviews.Author: slatsyrc
Reviews.Content: My husband and I stayed at Las Casitas for 6 days. We read all of the tripadvisor reviews so knew in advance of some of the issues: Cleanliness - the room was nice, but we had an issue with broken glass on the rug, there was mildew on the bedskirt, there was an unidentified curly hair stuck on a wash rag, bath towels had lots of stains on them, the bathtub had alot of mildew growing, the refrigerator needs updating, the phone had not been cleaned in months as I put a clorox wipe to it and cleaned it up pretty good. Location - Nice, not too far from San Juan, but I think if I would've done it all over I would have stayed in a beach front property near San Juan. Palomino was nice, but would've been easier to just walk to the beach than have to take the ferry. Room - room was nice, no luggage racks, was very noisy, could hear our neighbors almost like they were in the same room, the palm tree outside on the balcony kept making noise all night with the wind. They upgraded us to an ocean view for free, so I can't complain much. Parking at Las Casitas is free, but sometimes not so convenient. Service - Service was better than expected, we did ask for alot of things like towels and ice which they brought right away, bottled water is free, you just have to request it. We did have a hard time finding the check-in location and drove around alot, they could make that more clear for us prior to our arriving. Wish they would explain more about how things work upon checking in, like we paid for the breakfast plan, but then were surprised when they brought us a check for our first breakfast that was over $60! The waiter told us it would be cleared upon checkout, but then we didn't know if we still had to tip since there was a service charge on there. We had to call the front desk, they could not explain the service charge, but it turns out that it was not on there after all, just our additional gratuity. All of the waitstaff at restaurants were pretty good. Value - Everything is overpriced here so you should be prepared for that prior to your stay. I think our room rate was high, food and drinks were definitely absurd at most places. We ate at Ballyhoo one night, two sandwiches and 4 drinks was over $70 and not that good; Pizza place was so-so and cost about $60 for two of us, definitely upgrade to the breakfast plan as if you don't, it will be at least $30/person for continental breakfast buffet, Iguanas at Palomino Island is also pricey and you don't have a choice once you are there since no outside food or drinks are allowed on Palomino (they don't check your bags so you can sneak in some food/drinks there). Nothing is free there, not the snorkeling equipment, nothing except the chairs and umbrellas if you can snag one. Wireless internet was $15/day and we had a weak signal when we used it. Sleep Quality - We did not sleep very good as you cannot change the room temperature in the room warmer than 72 degrees and you can hear literally everything from your neighbors around you. Tips - - Definitely stop by the Walmart or grocery store in Fajardo to get drinks for your room (other than water) and snacks for any excursions you may take. - If you plan on snorkeling, buy your own set before you come as they charge $8 each for the snorkel and $8 for the fins for a half day. You can buy your own after 2 days. - Take advantage of the free water (Dasani) - Wear shoes that don't slip easy as the whole place is covered in ceramic tile and with the constant raining it is very slippery. - Bring a flashlight, lots of their lights do not work on property - Don't plan to use the infinity pool at night as it is creepy, no lights and no towels. - If you have a rental car, take advantage of the local restaurants like El Estacion and Ole Leolai. Pasion was so-so and over priced. - Pass on the Vieques trip, we ended up spending only 2 hours on Vieques, but took us over 4 hours in travel time driving and taking the ferry and was not better than Palomino and you definitely have to bring your own food & drinks as the beaches are remote and have no vendors on them. I would recommend staying here if you mainly plan to stay on property and if you are with family. It's very nice and safe, funicular and ferry was convenient although we stayed during off-season. If you are younger and not with a family I would stay at a beachfront hotel near San Juan.

Reviews.Title: “Fantastic trip!”
Reviews.Author: BioBay2010
Reviews.Content: We are a family of four with a teenager and a five year-old, so our review will be from a family perspective with younger kids. We have stayed at the Ritz Carlton in Montego Bay, Jamaica, and we remember some of the negative reviews that hotel had received. It was a nice hotel, with a Caribbean feel, and we enjoyed our stay there and will stay there again when we go back to Montego Bay. As a result, we were not deterred when we saw some negative reviews for the El Conquistador. Location: We wanted paradise and that is why we went with the El Conquistador. The location was breath taking and it was completely worth it. There were a lot of comments about the hotel rooms needing some updating, but we did not spend too much time in the hotel room. In addition, our hotel room was in great condition. If we wanted the nightlife, we would have left the kids with a babysitter and gone on a night trip to San Juan. Checking In: It was a long trip, with our flight being delayed and getting the rental car. We ended up driving up to the main building of the El Conquistador. Let's just say it was a long day and we were tired. Fortunately, John Henao was at the front desk and was helping us. He was very professional and courteous. It was people like him, who made our stay wonderful. He was able to get us in and out in no time. Miguel, one of the bell hops, got us on our way and we got lost (because I was driving). Luckily, Sergio escorted us to our room and helped us with our bags. Sergio got us some bottled water for our fridge, which was a nice touch. Jesus brought us some sheets for our sofa bed and Pablo brought us some new keys. The day got better and our trip was back on a good note. Concierge: Lillian, who works in the Manor house, is awesome! She was extremely polite and very professional. She asked us about our plans and gave us information about activities that would compliment our planned activities. She had some better maps and some additional activities that we would not have thought of. She was the type of person that I would expect at a Waldorf or a Ritz. Restaurants: If you have read other reviews, you will notice that the hotel is lacking in a local flavor restaurant. As a result, we did venture out from the property for some meals. However, we did breakfast everyday, which was part of our package. If not, if would have been around $100.00 per day, so the package definitely paid for itself (we stayed for 8 days/7 nights). We ate at the breakfast area in Las Casitas, which was never busy (bonus). Ricardo and everyone else were very friendly, and they were a nice start to our day. We went to the Cafe Bella Vista, which was on the terrace by the main pool. This was a great place for the family. Max, who works at the Manor house, recommended it, and the kids loved it out of all of the places we went to. The hostess was very nice and our waitress, Leydi, was awesome! Our kids had the Calamari, which was good (but Calizo was better). We had pizzas here and they were great. Our tab was over $100 before the tip, but I remember the food being expensive at the Ritz in Jamaica. In addition, if you go the Atlantis in the Bahamas it is expensive there. Pools/Water Park: We stayed in the Las Casitas wing, but we made it to see almost all of the pools. The pools were nice, especially with the Infinity pool in the Las Casitas wing. During different times of the day, you could always find peace at one of the pools. The water park was nice and it was the kids favorite. The water slides are fun and easy enough for kids to go on. My son did two out of the three big slides, but I did not think he was ready for the big drop slide. Even though there was a child, who was younger, that went on the slide. The water park also has an Infinity edge in part of the pool, which was a nice touch. The water park has more younger kids than older kids, but there were still teenagers and twenty-somethings at the water park during our stay. The water park is big enough for you to have your own area, if you don't want to sit by kids. However, you will still hear them if you are not listening to music. Palimino Island (private beach): The beach was awesome! My wife loved the beach area the most. We had read reviews and brought water shoes. I did not use them most of the time, but my wife and kids did not want to go into the water without them. They have plenty of activities, if you don't want to lay out and go in the water all day. They had a basketball court, with a few balls to play with (free to use). The basketball court is concrete, so you can actually dribble. However, it was a little warm for my 13 year old, so she needed to use her shoes (not a bad thing). There is a sand volleyball court and a volleyball (free to use). There is a miniature golf course, which looked like fun and was popular. There is horseback riding, jet skis, snorkeling, rafts, kayaks, and so much more. Plus, there is a casual restaurant with a bar, a shop, and another bar area. Jose at Iguanas was a really friendly. Spa: My daughter wanted to get the works done, but she was too young for the spa. As a result, my wife did not go and took one for the team. When we went to the Ritz, our daughter had been able to get spa treatments, so it was a little disappointing. However, I liked that the spa was its own stand alone building. It has a salon, fitness center, men's and women's area (which include showers, jacuzzi, steam room, and lounge area), spa area, and a tea lounge. I got two spa treatments while I was there, and they were great. The hot stone was one of the better ones, and the Golden Door treatment got out the kinks from carrying my son through the rain forest, Old San Juan, etc. Casino: I had envisioned something larger, until I saw a you tube video of someone walking by the casino. As a result, I was not let down with how small it is. However, they did have a nice assortment of games and a few tables to play at. The tables were full during the Lakers/Celtics games, and it was pretty full during this time. There is a bar in the Casino, called 21. Make sure that you get a Mojito from Keyra. She made the best Mojitos on the island. The drinks are expensive, and can run $10-$15 for non-beer drinks. However, I saw people buying $13+ drinks and leaving $1 tips. Personally, I felt like it was ridiculous that they were upset with the prices, but taking it out on the staff. My tips were more generous, and I realize that these people might have families that they need to support (in addition to themselves). Golf and Tennis: We did not play either, during our stay. Resort Fee: This hotel has a resort fee. I have encountered this before in other places that I have stayed, especially in Vegas, so I was not surprised. When you look at it per day, it is not that bad. Parking: I have seen a lot of complaints on having to pay for parking. I have stayed downtown Salt Lake City, and I had to pay for parking at the hotel that I stayed atâ€¦ Downtown Chicago, San Francisco, etc. all charge for parking, so I do not see why it is a surprise for a resort to charge for parking. However, the Las Casitas area you do not have to pay for parking, so keep that in mind when booking your room. You will not be able to park if you do not stay there, because the guard would not let you in. Getting around: We rented a car, because we felt that it would be the most efficient use of our time. We wanted to experience Puerto Rico without being herded like cattle. It was well worth it. Overall: Our stay was great and we would definitely stay here again in the future. I think that it was worth the money and it was a great time. We went to Walmart for groceries for our room and that helped cut down some of the expenses. Cons: The room keys were a problem for my family, in the Las Casitas section. The room keys can get demagnetized, which happened to my wife. Once she found out she no longer had that problem. The major problem was the room key would still work, but the entry key to get to the room might change. This happened when a family moved in the suite above ours, but we were not aware that this could happen. We got back from Old San Juan, on our last night, and we were not able to get to our room door. As a result, I called the Manor house to get some new keys. They said someone would be there with three new keys. It is past 11 pm and our 5 year old is melting down from the long day. We called back in 13 minutes and they said they had sent someone. I could have walked to the manor house in less time, but I was told that someone was coming so I stayed with my family. After 20 minutes had passed, I called the Manor house again and no one answered, so we got transferred to the main operator and they got security to us. In all we waited 30 minutes with my son crying for part of that time, but the person never made it in the 30 minutes with the 3 keys. Hector was nice enough to open the door for us, and mentioned not to close the door that leads to both of the rooms. However, we had left it open when we left, so the other family must have closed it. The funny thing is our keys worked on our room doors. Now if Lillian had been in town, I know that this would have been resolved sooner. Also, if they said that the bell hops were at the main hotel or helping someone else, I would have walked down to the Manor house. We might have made it more difficult for housekeeping (not on purpose), when we closed the door to the suites. This speed bump was minor and our trip was fantastic, so this does not take away any stars from the hotel.

Reviews.Title: “If Service isn't important to you - Las Casitas is the place for YOU!”
Reviews.Author: shupemom
Reviews.Content: We just returned from our family vacation at Las Casitas resort. I debated about posting my review while still there and things were fresh in my mind but then I decided to wait a week to see if my feelings had changed. I had read the numerous reviews on this site and we still decided on this property. I must say that I cannot in all good conscience rate this property a 4 or 5 and my husband who is extremly easy going, agreed. The grounds and surrounding area were breathtaking. The photos on the website do not even do the property any justice. I will cut to the chase, and state I rated this property a 3 because I was severely disappointed with the way we were made to feel during our stay. Having visited the stunning 5 star resorts in Maui, the Bahamas, Cancun, Aruba and here in the Phoenix metro-area - service is extremely important to us. I will typically book concierge level rooms since I appreciate the extra personal touch. Having spent $600+ per night for a 2 bedroom/2 bath casita with an ocean view - you would think that the service would translate. The staff at Las Casitas had an uncaring attitude, almost to the point whenever we called or went to the manor house for assistance - the staff members acted like we interrupted their break time. * We used the Hotel airport transfer for $74 per person. We had to carry and load our own bags - which should have given me a glimpse of what kind of service (or lack thereof) we were in for. * We checked in and found that the casita had no hot water. I contacted housekeeping and concierge 3 times regarding the problem and in all 3 instances they said they were going to send someone right over. Finally, when my kids were screaming from the showers, the 4th phone call the associate tried to direct me to where the switch was in the kitchen to activate the water heater. After further searching we were able to find it - and no one assisted. Further, for that kind of price - why wasn't the water heater switched on prior to our arrival? * When we checked in, housekeeping failed to place wash towels in the room. Numerous requests were made during morning and turn down services for 4 days - no wash towels. The evening before we were scheduled to check-out, wash towels finally appeared. * WiFi - non-existent in the casita. The concierge associate actually asked me to move my laptop around the perimeter of the casita, that the wifi was fine and it had to be my laptop. I had visions of standing on my patio, on one foot and holding my laptop in the air to try to receive a signal. NOT! Again, no one came to trouble shoot or assist. * Golf - Cart service to the El Conquistador next door was a challenge. Which, by the way is where all the restaurants are. My Mother, who does not walk very good - came with us and walking around this resort the first day almost made me check out and go elsewhere. The cart sometimes would take us to the front door and othertimes dropped us up 1 hill to walk the rest of the way. * The Water Park - fun - but cost prohibitive for most. $19.95 per person per day, no discount for staying at the resort -- shame on you for charging that for hotel guests. * Concierge - asking them for dinner reservations off property one evening was a lesson in futility. Concierge desks I am accustomed to have a large book with restaurant menus. Not at Las Casitas Manor House. Actually the associate looked at me like I was nuts when I asked. * Restaurants were OK. I am not going to complain about the prices, because I was on vacation.Stingray had an amazing menu and food was delicious. * Fajardo - the resort is located 1 hour from the airport, on the north eastern tip of the island. In my opinion it is way too far from anything. I certainly like places that are not anywhere multiple high-rise beach resorts USA, but this bordered on the ridiculous. * The private island was nice, my kids rented jet skis and had a blast. * The infinity pool was the place we hung out most days, but again - they claimed they had pool service that was non-existent. We arrived and our first day at the pool was Sunday. There was pool service that day but after that, we didn't see anyone until Thursday - the day before we checked out. If we wanted anything we had to go get it ourselves and then again, we were interrupting. These things might be trivial to some, but this hopefully paints a picture that the overall service at this beautiful property was very poor. I hope someone in Management reads reviews on trip advisor and makes a major overhaul. Originally, we were going to stay at the Ritz Carlton - but I found Las Casitas and thought the water slides, private beach and more room to move around in the casita was all a bonus. Unfortuantely, I would not recommend this property to any of my friends and next time we visit Puerto Rico, we will stay where I originally planned - the Ritz Carlton!

Reviews.Title: “My first time to stay at a waldorf...”
Reviews.Author: DRC1971
Reviews.Content: My first time to stay at a waldorf Astoria collection and I have to say... HUGE Dissapointment! I have visited and even ate at other waldorf properties... This UNDER whelmed me. From the rooms to the food to the famed golden door spa... Disapointment all around. The food was torture.. To find a decent meal on the property was painful in fact down right maddening to tears! The rooms needed a remodle..just all around yuck. The views were breath-taking. The spa; cool jacuzzi, showers were nice but need new shower heads and shower doors, no tea, bottled water or fruit offered.. No towels, no spa hostess.. 20% auto grat.. No good. 1st treatment was awesome , 2nd treatment (facial) the woman beat my face in.. Couldn't wait to get out of there. Got bumped off an activity tour (hiking in the rain forest) and the activity concierge had nothing to say nor an alternative. Bummer. All around cheesy, cruise ship feel (with the lovely (not) band in the lobby that they call their night club) evrything shuts down at midnight and a taxi charges 20$ each way to take you down the hill 5 min. Eat at a different restaurant.. All in all a tourist trap.. Raped for your hard earned money and un' return poor food, service, and experience. nor an alternative.

Reviews.Title: “Beyond Customer Service with Gorgeous Views”
Reviews.Author: jcosials
Reviews.Content: I went to an annual convention and I was very pleased with the customer service from the moment I arrived. I want to share my experience of an exceptional employee, Carlos A. Mangual with his customer service. His calm, patient manner was a great help to me when my frustration was high. His remarkable problem-solving abilities were excellent and beyond normal duties. If the quality of his services is an indication of future success, then Las Casitas Resort has a very bright future. Carlos' efforts in recovering my forgotten items during my last stay at Las Casitas couple of weeks ago were excellent. I appreciate the time he took to assist me. Thank you for the prompt and courteous service you have given me. Best - Jose

Reviews.Title: “Best Hotel/Resort In Puerto Rico”
Reviews.Author: sabastianvip
Reviews.Content: Beautiful property! This has been my second visit to this resort in less than a year. The addition of the water park, the infiniti pool and the service, are the reasons why we are still coming back to this resort. Our Butler Carlos is without question the best we have seen so far, he went beyond his duties and even give us his personal phone number in case we needed him on his days off.

Reviews.Title: “Bed Bugs! NOT a resort of Waldorf Astoria quality. Should be 3.5 stars.”
Reviews.Author: Vista30
Reviews.Content: We just returned from a long weekend at Las Casitas. The property is beautiful, with lush landscapes, gorgeous pools. My main issue with this resort is that it is billed as a Waldorf Astoria property but is not at the standard of their other properties, especially for the cost. Upon arrival we were unceremoniously dropped at our doorstep with no official tour or introduction to the very large property by our "personal butler". The staff had not bothered to flip the switch on the water heater, so for the first night we had cold water only until we figured this out. This casita (villa) had no slippers or robes as adveritsed. Upon calling the service desk, we were told that the resort was "in the process of upgrading to a Waldorf Astoria property", so not all the units had all amenities yet. They did manage to find us some robes and slippers later that evening. The front desk had initially told us we were being taken to a room with 2 double beds, but when we arrived there was a sofabed and a king, so the second day, they did make an effort to accomodate us and found us a room with 2 double beds and we moved. This was after another incident in which we called and complained because housekeeping left a diaper on the nighttable -- and no it was not ours. The second villa was clearly an upgraded/more newly renovated unit, but still no robes. These rooms were nothing spectacular either. The 3rd morning I woke up with one bite, the next day we both woke up with several bed bug bites, despite the fact that the room seemed basically clean. The resort restaurants are very expensive ($10 hot dog, $15 burger). You should take a cab to town and eat at the local restaurants which are very good. Also, ask the cab drivers for rates on discounted Bio Bay, Rainforest and Old San Juan tours, depending on the size of your group, you can save up to half off the hotel's rates. I was very disappointed with this property given I have stayed in Waldorf and Ritz calibre properties in the past, and would not stay here again due to the fact that I paid hundreds of dollars for what was in reality a 3.5 star resort and to be bitten by bed bugs!

Reviews.Title: “Great for relaxing beach vacation.”
Reviews.Author: bpulitzer
Reviews.Content: We travelled to Las Casitas in March and had a perfect vacation. I admit that, having read some of the reviews before going, I was a bit worried, but I'm happy to say that we had a fantastic time in a beautiful resort. Some points for those scheduled to/considering a visit: - Do take advantage of any package that includes breakfast, as the run-of-the mill continental will run at least $25/pp. - We rented a car for a week but are unsure if it was financially advantageous. It was nice to have the convenience (off-site dinners, driving to the Port Authority to take a ferry to Vieques), though if you're trying to save, I suspect the hotel could have arranged ad hoc trips (everything is within 10 minutes). - We did not explore Old San Juan or the Rainforest, though we heard the latter was worth the trip (in particular, the waterfalls and canopy make for outstanding photos/swimming). - Go in with eyes open: obvioulsy everything on the resort is more expensive (you won't find a watered-down pina colada under $13), so you can either buy food/alcohol and keep it in your room, go off-site for your meals, or relax and enjoy the resort's restaurants. We ate at three of the restaurants - The Strip House (which isn't cheap, but has outstanding cuts), Stingray (again, not cheap, but the variety and quality is top notch and the atmosphere - wait for a seat outside - is fantastic), and Blossoms (we ate at the sushi bar here - not the best, but I've read that the seafood is some of the freshest anywhere). - We got the sense from the concierge that there are certain off-site restaurants that get pushed more than others. We tried Passion our first night - fine (the mofango was very good), but atmosphere ho-hum. If you have just one night, definitely go to Ole Leilolai - a wonderful tapas restaurant just 5 minutes from the resort with great staff and outdoor deck. Menu is creative and diverse - something for everyone. - Palomino Beach is fantastic - tons of chairs/shade, so it shouldn't be too hard to find an open spot. Food at the nearby bar is fine... ~$25 for a bucket of (5) beers which you can bring back to your chairs. I'm VERY happy I listened to posters recommending bringing water shoes - the ocean floor is all coral. Also, snorkeling here is worth ~an hour, though be careful around the reefs, as it can be sharp. - The hotel arranges scuba/snorkel trips every day (not sure why there wasn't more mention of it in the tour books?) - fantastic and well-run operation. We lucked out and a large group had chartered a boat to go out to Culebra for a full day - a destination and duration not usually offered. As they were looking to fill a few remaining seats, we grabbed them. WELL worth the money and full day trip, though I"m sure any of the trips are great. - Las Casitas offers complimentary water. We called to ask for some to be brougt to our room, and they brought 8 bottles. We should have asked earlier! - Infinity Pool is amazing. Could have easily spent days here. - Golden Door Spa was fine, but a mani/pedi ran $130+ (a price I have no problem paying if the experience is worth it, but I found everything from the service to the environment lackluster). - Nights are quiet, but if the casino isn't your thing, you can always order banana splits to go, rent a DVD from the front desk office, and relax in one's room. - Vieques is fun for a day trip (just $2 ferry to the island and back) - as is Culebra, I suspect - but go for the beaches, as you won't find any town centers or shops. Vans on the island are frequent and cheap (~$6 to get from one end of the island to the other). Do take the opportunity to visit Esperanza's boardwalk. - The views from the bluffs are amazing, so ask for an ocean view room. Would definitely return.

Reviews.Title: “Remains a key option in Puerto Rico”
Reviews.Author: cruz30
Reviews.Content: I have stayed several times at El Conquistador Hotel, first time at Las Casitas and overall it was a great experience, service from the Casitas Staff was top notch. There is a trolley service that takes you to the hotel, but las casitas has it own amazing infinity pool overlooking the Atlantic ocean, the view is priceless. So you get to benefit from the Hotel facilities (private beach, etc..) while staying at a quieter and in my opinion better place.

Reviews.Title: “Amazing setting, but not quite what we expected from a 4/5 star property”
Reviews.Author: stl-sna-mvy
Reviews.Content: If you are seeking a killer view that you'll never forget or simply want to stay in an upscale spot in Fajardo, this is the place. On the other hand, if you are seeking five star service and accommodations commensurate with the view, you may be disappointed. Our casita was disappointing: the beds were small (double, not queen) and in need of replacement due to sagging, the bathroom was a bit tired, the TV old and erratic, and the AC intermittent (subsequently repaired by AC contractor). Sound proofing between rooms was very bad--always heard doors in unit next to us slamming. It should be noted that the staff is very friendly and the grounds are well maintained and inviting. The infinity pool is everything you might hope for! The property is built into a steep hillside, so be prepared for a lot of up and down. We were fine with that but if you are not in shape, watch out. Breakfast was served at one of the 2 pools and it was delightful, albeit simple. Service was barely OK. We were on a breakfast meal plan. If you are not, be prepared to spend $20+ for your continental breakfast. We did not have dinner at the property, but we did have cocktails. The setting for the bar was out of this world. So were the prices: The tangerine mohito including tax and manadatory tip was about $20; the Margarita made with premium tequila was about $30. The drinks were not large. You will need 2 drinks to get a buzz. Ouch! While the staff was friendly, the service was unreliable. Be prepared to submit your request for special assistance 2 or more times. We sought a rollaway or air mattress for teenage child. Had to ask 3 times before they got it right. The first time the air mattress had a slow leak. Child slept on the hard floor that night. Golden Door Spa facility on the grounds is magnificent. First class! Clearly a highlight. Exclusive Palomino Island beach area (accessible only by hotel boat) is very attractive but the beach is more for sunning and wading, not swimming or riding surf. Lunch at the beach cafe was fine: beer was cold, sandwiches and fare perfectly acceptable. Hotel water park with separate admission was small, but very enjoyable even for older kids and adults. Families with younger kids or tweens will love it.- Did not play golf but the course looked well maintained. Bottom line: Rooms need a real face lift if they are to play in the big leagues. If we had paid full price, we would not have been happy. However, for what we paid ($300/night including breakfast), it was acceptable. If the beds had been larger and more comfortable, we would have given the overall experience a rating of "B".

Reviews.Title: “Better than Ever”
Reviews.Author: eatrite
Reviews.Content: My extended family (husband, children, grandchildren) has vacationed for a week at Las Casitas for 7 years. Our recent stay was exceptional. The water park is a great addition to swimming in the beautiful small pools and playing tennis daily, Staff is friendly and the butler service has improved considerably. All of our requests were met within a reasonable time. The only negative remains the better restaurants. With the exception of Stingrays, the other two have mediocre food and service. I highly recommend a family vacation at las Casitas.

Reviews.Title: “Really enjoyed our stay”
Reviews.Author: rdking1998
Reviews.Content: My husband and I spent three nights in an ocean view one-bedroom at Las Casitas. The room was pretty nice. Like a lot of the resort, it was just a bit dated, but very comfortable and well-furnished anyway. The kitchen area was small, but we only used it for breakfast and snacks, so it was fine. The deck area was also a bit small, but we had a great view. Just beautiful. We loved having the pool right outside the door, and it was pretty quiet at Las Casitas, which is just what we were going for. The only real problem was that when it rained, which it did two of the days we were there, water got in under the front door of the casita. It clearly was an ongoing issue, judging by the rust stains on the leg of a table in the entry way, but it took two calls each time to get someone in housekeeping to bring us extra towels to address the issue. It wasn't that big of a deal, but it was annoying. Other than that, housekeeping itself was excellent. They did a great job daily, and it was very clean when we checked in. We loved the spa. Great facilities, great services, just top notch. We also enjoyed the three restaurants we tried at the resort. Everyone we encountered at the resort (both Las Casitas and El Con) was friendly and helpful. Overall, we had a great trip.

Reviews.Title: “Bed Bug Bites, Poor Service....Not worth your Money!”
Reviews.Author: lilbellachka
Reviews.Content: We heard so many great things about this Hotel that we just couldnâ€™t wait to arrive. When we where booking the hotel I told the girl that we would arrive at around 6 A.M. she told me that if a room was available we would be accommodate and early check in. However, once we got there a rude lady at front desk told us once she already checked us in that "since we arrived before check in we would be charges for the night before" which was not the information provided previously once booking the trip. At first we where given a room with NO Balcony even though they said we would have one and the sheets felt like we slept on sand paper from the lint. Once we went to front desk they were nice to accommodate a nicer room in the Marina which faced the water and right next to the pool, but the walk to it was over 15 minutes. We traveled there for a wedding with over 150 guests. Half if not most found little bed bug bites on them which front desk told us were Mosquito bites, right! Upon carful reviewed once we arrived back home we found out that they where bed bug bites. We called back to see if they would provide any help and they told us that we would need to be seen by the doctor in the hotel, well HELLO we tried but were turned away when we were there. When confronting the front desk we where not even given any repellants just told to go buy it on our own and go on about our day. Once we where checking out we where not informed that the check out was at 11 A.M. so when I got the bell hop at 10 A.M. they arrived almost an hour later and we were forced to pay $65 extra for "late check out". If they moved a little faster maybe I wouldnâ€™t have to pay daily $20 for the service that was not needed. Speaking of charges lets talk about $3 daily charge for housekeeping. The lady came at 5 P.M. almost at he end of the end of the day and not only do they "save" on water by not changing sheets but they also do not provide clean towels until I had to beg for them to be brought to out room. I get the whole idea of "going green" but in Puerto Rico where the weather is over 85 degrees daily and its always moist because its right on the water, you cant possible have dry and clean sheets for 3 days. Thatâ€™s how BED BUG BITES arrive! I had a few but the people we came with had MAJOR bites all over their bodies. The new extension is beautiful but it only has conference rooms, and the over all views are amazing. The activities provided were great and lots of fun, the pools were huge and lots of fun, the restaurants in the hotel are great , the weather was also wonderful the entire time we stayed but the employees are not as nice especially those working at the front desk. No one seems to help when we tries telling them about our issues, instead they looked frustrated with us. Waldorf Astoria should DEFINITELY think twice before putting there name on this hotel.

Reviews.Title: “A great week in Puerto Rico”
Reviews.Author: eternalvacationer
Reviews.Content: We stayed the week of Jan. 16th to 23rd in a 2 bedroom casita and we had one of the best family vacations we have ever taken. We have previously stayed at the many nice hotels including, The reef-atlantis, Ritz St. Thomas, Marriott Grand caymen, Moon palace cancun, Westin Cabo. Disney Cruise and this was one of the better quality trips we have taken. The hotel was extremely nice with wonderful views from our room and the infiniti pool is wonderful. The casual dining spots in the Casitas are very relaxing for breakfast and lunch, and much nicer than the grand buffet at the main hotel. Our kids enjoyed the water park for 2 of our days and we went to palamino island for one of our days. We all enjoyed both of these activities and the beack on the island is wonderful. They have a basketball court on the island along with horseback, and many watersports. Our kids, 2 boys aged 10 and 12, enjoyed the pingpong at the main pool, while my wife and I enjoyed drinks at the pool bar overlooking the sea below. We took a side trip one day to do the zip lining at Marchesa forest which was an easier course than the El Yungue zip line and it was a great family activity. The kids did very well with this and had no worries. I was afraid the kids might have been afraid of the more challenging El Yungue, But considering how easily they did the course in Marchesa, we probably would have done just as well on the El Yungue Zip line. Another side trip we took was to the Hacienda Carabali ranch were we all rode 4 wheelers. It was a great trip. We took the 2 hour tour which takes you up into the mountains and our guide stopped to let us swim in a river up in the rain forest. They also offer horseback riding and they have a nice restaurant-bar. Back to the hotel, We enjoy the restaurants contrary to some other reviewers. Stingrays in the marina offer very fresh fish every nignt as well as tradition favorites. The Italian restaurant was very good one evening, and as I stated we really liked the breakfast offered in the casitas village. The kids loved the cookies at the store at the top of of the funicular and we also liked the casual food at the water park. One day I went golfing with the boys and the course was excellent. While we golfed, my wife went to the spa and she had a wonderful day. We had dinner at 2 outside restaurants and both were wonderful. The first was called El Varadero which is in the marina area in fajardo which is only about one mile from the main gate. When you drive into Fajardo, the marina is on the left. As you enter the marina there is a gate that you will come to and you must just tell the gaurd you are going to the restaurant and they will let you through. We had Breakfast here and dinner one evening which was extremely good. It is also waterside dining and offers a great atmosphere. There number is [--] We also had dinner at La Parrilla which is in the Kiosks in Luguillo. The Kiosks don't look like much in appearances, but La Parilla was very nice inside and the food was the best. My wife and I both had traditional Puerto Rican dishes, while the kids split a 3 pound lobster. It was a great experience. They let the kids pick there own live lobster from a tank and it was delicious. Lastly, As you can tell from all of our side trips, we rented a car which I highly recommend. It was an easy drive from the airport and then you have it available to enyoy some of the activities that Puerto Rico has to offer. We found the people of Puerto Rico to be very friendly and happy to have us as visitors.

Reviews.Title: “Another wonderful vacation in paradise”
Reviews.Author: delbymom
Reviews.Content: This was our 3rd visit to Las Casitas and once again...it was truly paradise...everything there was perfect. The rooms were extremely clean...the help was terrific. Carlos the butler was the best and we will be returning next January.

Reviews.Title: “OK-but not worth the money”
Reviews.Author: poisonivvy
Reviews.Content: For a $400+ hotel room (1 bedroom casita), I was not completely impressed. Pros: The room was clean and stayed clean with help from the staff The rooms were split into a nice brand new kitchen, family room, balcony looking over the golf course, and small patio off of the actual bedroom. Big tub in the bathroom, but no jets An amazing infinity pool and jacuzzi that has a terrific view! Nice private island (they don't check/enforce the no outside food rule) Easygoing staff Won some money at their casino Cons: The yardwork started at 7:00 am with the leaf blower each day. I know the resort is big--but vacation is about sleeping in and for the first few days while still being on West Coast time was like a 3-4am wake up time. TVs are hit and miss--different channels in different rooms and not HD/Flat Screens Bathroom door is a sliding pocket door that needs some work/help Toilet room sink is standup and no cupboard/vanity storage room Having to wait for a golf cart if wanting to go up to main hotel (if after dark and wanting to walk, the path is not illuminated) Rooms not sound proofed and carry noise easily between casitas/main walkways/rooms Food overpriced (but what hotel doesn't?!?) If I were paying (instead of our parents paying for our honeymoon) I would not stay here for the price they ask. I'd go stay at a small B&B in Vieques (small island off of Fajardo and the main island) and spend maybe a day or two trip in Fajardo. You're not supposed to be in your room anyways--since you should be on the beach instead!

Reviews.Title: “5+ Star Vacation, Room, almost 5 stars”
Reviews.Author: sgeim
Reviews.Content: We are a family of 5 with 3 children ranging in ages from 8 to 13 and we visited Las Casitas Christmas week 2009. When researching Puerto Rico, we initially ruled out Las Casitas due to the travel time required to get to the beach. However, after looking at many other properties, our travel agent suggested we take another look here and we are thrilled that we did! Rooms: Las Casita are definitely they way to go versus hotel rooms at El Con. The hotel was crowded during our stay. The Casitas were always quiet and calm in comparison. Best of both worlds from my perspective. We stayed in a two bedroom Casita which was huge, comfortable and always immaculately clean. We were in the North Village a few steps away from the Casitas CafÃ© and one of the Casitas pools. My overall impression of the Casitas from the outside was that the South Village appeared newer. I did not see the inside of a South Village Casita, but they appeared to have some newer fixtures and newer front doors. Our Casita was, according to the front desk, refurbished within the last month. The kitchen/living room area had new looking furniture, granite counters, and stainless steel appliances giving it a great look. The cabinets appeared not to be new, but recently painted. The bathrooms were all clean, but the fixtures, such as the tub and sink looked older. Also the closet and cabinet doors throughout the casita were much older. So, while our Casita was lovely, it seems to me that the renovations were not as thorough as they should have been. This makes me wonder what the Casitas that have not yet been refurbished must look like. We enjoyed the North Village because it was an easy walk over to the hotel as well as the tennis courts/golf course and the Golden Door Spa area. We walked all around both the North and South Casitas and found that while you can walk to the hotel from the South Casitas, there are a lot of steps involved. Our refrigerator was stocked with water bottles each day. I wish I had known that before I dragged a heavy 24 bottle case of water in from the Supermarket! Transportation: We did not rent a car in Puerto Rico, but we went armed with the knowledge that if we needed to, we could rent one on property. We arranged for private transportation to and from the airport through our travel agent. I believe that the hotel offers a shared shuttle as well, but I think we actually paid a little less on our own. The private transfer was especially nice because we were able to stop at the supermarket on the way in so that we could stock up on breakfast foods and drinks. I assumed, based on prior reviews, that we would rent a little car just to leave the property for dinner once we got settled in, but we never felt the need. Beach/pools: For us, this was an extremely active vacation due to the travel time involved in getting to the beach. I really expected to go to the beach only once or twice, but we went almost every day. We even all enjoyed the boat ride over to Palomino Island. We loved the water sports at the beach (banana boat rides, kayaks etc). Keep in mind that EVERYTHING is ala-carte....even rafts at the beach, so it can get expensive. Water shoes are a MUST (even crocs do the trick) because there is a LOT of coral right off the beach. As long as your feet are protected, the ocean is awesomeâ€¦warm and Caribbean blue with almost non-existent surf. We ended each day with an early evening swim in the Casitas pools which are not open to the El Con guests and therefore very private and relaxing. In the Casitas Villages, there is always plenty of fresh, cold water at each pool and lots of towels. They even brought around complementary fresh fruit-kabobs on hot afternoons. We did not use the main pools at the hotel or the water park â€“ our kids preferred the beach. Food: As mentioned by almost all the TA posts, the food is expensive. But, we found it all to be good. This is the Caribbean and my experience is that most resort food in the Caribbean is expensive. People always seem surprised by this...we just expect it. We ate at three of the four "upscale" restaurants on the property. Blossoms, which is a hibachi/Chinese restaurant, had good food and generous portions. It was extremely expensive and no different than eating in a hibachi restaurant at home. My kids loved it, but I could have skipped that one. We also ate at the Strip House (very good steak house) and Stingrays (excellent seafood). I liked Stingrays because it is located at the marina and we were able to eat outside and enjoy the beautiful Caribbean night. Blossoms, The Strip House and Piccolo (Italian...we cancelled our reservation) were all inside the main hotel. We also ate at a few of the more casual bar/restaurants sprinkled throughout the property. Their menu's were more limited, but always tasty (and in most cases, more readily accommodating to a picky 8 year old). They, too, tend to be on the expensive side but not nearly as much as the Big Four upscale restaurants. Plus, they are almost all outdoor cafe type places which is my vacation preference. My biggest criticism of the food would have to be the lack of local flavor. Most menus were very similar to those found in the continental US. I would have like to see some more local and/or general Caribbean options as well. Service: We found the service to be wonderful. Our butler checked in with us every day and provided us with a lot of helpful information. With very few exceptions, the staff was friendly, helpful and extremely accommodating everywhere we went on the property. Resort as a whole: This place is beyond beautiful. It is almost impossible not to be awed by your surroundings. The reason that I did not give this resort 5 starts (although I would have given it 4.5 if I could) is that there are a number of little things that needed attention. Most of them are easily fixed items. For example, our first night at the resort, I had to call maintenance and security about 5 times to fix little things such as our front door lock malfunctioning, lack of a previously requested roll a way bed and a safe that malfunctioned with our belongings in it. After that, there always seemed to be something just slightly off such as the way we had to space our showers to ensure that we all had hot water or the set of bi-fold closet doors that was constantly falling off track . None of these issues were insurmountable, but a true five star property would not have these issues. The Bottom Line: We thoroughly enjoyed our stay at Las Casitas and I would recommend it whole-heartedly to anyone considering Puerto Rico as a vacation destination. If we return to Puerto Rico, we will definitely stay here again!

Reviews.Title: “Breathtaking Views and Pool. Excellent Service. Not a resort for beach lovers.”
Reviews.Author: KateOK
Reviews.Content: My college-age daughter & I took a long weekend away before the Christmas holiday season began. Puerto Rico met our criteria: non-stop flight, guaranteed warm weather, and easy immigration. After reading about Las Casitas on Trip Advisor, I booked through the Waldorf website, instead of other vacation web engines. Through the Waldorf site, I was able to secure exactly what type of room and location I wanted . Las Casitas is a smaller, newer accomodation attached to the very large Conquistador Resort. So glad I took the advice of TA'ers. And I found that all the reviews were spot-on. We flew into San Juan and took the hotel motorcoach I had booked through the concierge. The motorcoach cost $70 dollars for the two of us. We did not rent a car for this short trip. The motorcoach was pleasant. The driver was good. It takes about 45-60 minutes from the airport to the hotel. Very easy check-in at Las Casitas. The service was excellent throughout our 3 and 1/2 day stay. Little things were a miss in our condo: a faucet handle off, problems with on of the Tv's, no robes....and they were all quickly remedied. Las Casitas gives you a "butler", and he called us every day, leaving his personal cell phone. I never used him, but went through the conceirge instead because it was just more convenient for me to press a button on the house phone then to figure out how to call the butler. If you are at the Casitas, one has access to everything at the resort, plus everything at the Conquistador. Those staying at Conquistador cannot use Casitas facilities. Las Casitas has a gorgeous infinity pool. The views from my condo balcony and the pool hinted of stays I've had in the Greek Islands. Just breathtaking. There is a small lunch place attached to the infinity pool area, with a limited menu. There is a separate breakfast cafe, with a buffet offered each morning. In short, here are the highlights and caveats: 1. Condos are very clean, up to date, and we had a to die-for ocean view. 2. Service at Las Casitas was excellent, from the concierge, to each server 3. The pools, grounds, equipment were well mantained. 4. The cliffside pool was gorgeous. But keep in mind: 1. To get to the beach one must: walk to Conquistador or take golf cart (about 5 minutes), Take elevator down part of cliff to funicular (another 10 minutes). Wait at funicular and take this down to marina.(15 minutes). Wait for hydro-ferry, get on, and ride 15-20 minutes across water to hotel-owned island. Very small beach. Funky and fun. But teeny. Because it took so long to get over to the island beach, during holiday season, my daughter and I only went over there once. Getting from our condo to the beach took us an hour. The ferry runs on the hour, so if you miss it, you have to wait 60 minutes for the next ride out to the island. It is just tedious. It's an ok beach, but if you are a "beach person"--this may not be the spot for you. 2. The tab can add up. Because it's an island, and it's a resort, food and drink are pricey. 3. My daughter and I are active and fit, and were trying to take stairs any time we could. But the hotel decided not to finish stairs going from the Marina up the cliff . So, there was really no way to circumvent the long holiday lines at the funicular or elevator. Sometimes, if the funicular is down, the hotel runs buses from the boat at the marina up the hills to the main hotel. Just not while we were there. ** There is a fantastic water park, which we didn't use, but people really raved about it. The dinner choices are broadbased. We ate at the Sushi bar twice and at the Marina twice. We were not interested in the steakhouse or the italian restaurants, which were the other dinner options. *** We had a great time. We don't gamble, so didn't go to the casino. We also didn't use the Golden Door Spa, ...just chilled on our own, read, slept, swam. The Marina area is very pretty and wonderful at night.
